```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE)
```

## Read in data



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
animal_weight<-read_csv("_data/animal_weight.csv",
                        show_col_types = FALSE)
animal_weight
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

:::


## Describing the data

The animal weight data has the weight of 16 types of livestocks collected from 9 geographical areas. 

The pivoted dataset will have 144 rows/ cases and 3 columns of region, animal type and weight.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
animal_weight_longer<-pivot_longer(animal_weight, 
                                    col=-`IPCC Area`,
                                    names_to = "Livestock",
                                    values_to = "Weight")
animal_weight_longer
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 144 × 3
   `IPCC Area`         Livestock          Weight
   <chr>               <chr>               <dbl>

 3 Indian Subcontinent Buffaloes           295  
 4 Indian Subcontinent Swine - market       28

 6 Indian Subcontinent Chicken - Broilers    0.9
 7 Indian Subcontinent Chicken - Layers      1.8
 8 Indian Subcontinent Ducks                 2.7
 9 Indian Subcontinent Turkeys               6.8
10 Indian Subcontinent Sheep                28  
# … with 134 more rows
# ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows
```
:::
:::
